data.title: Large file support and hex binary file display
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.2

I'm using vs code as my first choice when editing code and multiple types of files. But there are two issues annoying me:
* Large file support. 
It can't open large data file like json or logging files that are important in my projects. It's not too large, just 50MB-200MB.
* Hex display of binary file. 
When I need to handle raw binary file it shows that VScode doesn't support this decode style. I don't need VSCode to decode the file, just show me binary number in hex or binary. Many web stream files are binary and I need to extract them. 

Thanks if you consider my suggestions.

data.title: Change extension order for Diff language id
data.body:
Currently the order is:
- `.patch`
- `.diff`
- `.rej`

This creates a visual issue when using different images for `diff` and `patch`.

Currently we on [vscode-icons](https://github.com/robertohuertasm/vscode-icons) do so and although the associated files get the correct image, in the `Language Mode` selection it shows the `patch` image and not the `diff` image.

Changing the order to:
- `.diff`
- `.patch`
- `.rej`

or
- `.diff`
- `.rej`
- `.patch`

should fix the issue.

data.title: Git Clone: Default clone into /tmp folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Feature suggestion:  To default git clone into the `/tmp` folder, or to at least allow settings for a default folder...

I typically use this to dig deeper into Github repos on Atom/VS Code, rather than browsing through their web interface.  So setting up `git clone` like this saves a lot of time and automatically purges my repos when I restart my comp.

This replicates the feature set for the [git-clone Atom package](https://github.com/brianchung808/git-clone).

data.title: Prevent editing of read-only files
data.body:
A small gripe, but one which gets me every time.
I use vscode with some auto-generated source files which are marked on disk as read-only. Because the auto-generated files appear similar to the normal source files in my project, I start to edit them and only discover when I try to save that I'm in the wrong file.

As well as #17621, it would be really useful to have a configurable editor option that prevents any editing of read-only files. Any keystrokes, pasting, etc are simply ignored.

data.title: Middleclick in Ubuntu Unity Launcher does not open a new window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Middle-click on the Unity Launcher Icon.
2. The load mouse indicator appears and disappears again. Then nothing happens.

This is breaking Ubuntus default behaviour of opening a new instance of the application upon a middle click. A left click brings the running app instance to the front or launches a new one (works) and a right click opens the context menu (works).

As a workaround I have to spawn a new window from the file menu each time I need a new instance, which feels really broken.

data.title: Allow variables to be displayed in a different base during debugging
data.body:
Integer variables are always displayed in decimal format in Locals, Watches and on hover.

It would be nice to have a context menu option to allow the values to be displayed in binary, octal or hexadecimal format, perhaps with a "debug.displayBase" option for a default configuration value.

data.title: Added github icon mapping for gitmodules file
data.body: By default we've github icon only for 3 files: .gitignore, .gitkeep,.gitattributes. The .gitmodules file provides sensible default URLs for each submodule, and is committed in the repository like any other versioned file. So I've added this mapping.

data.title: Performance issues when using several "code parsing" plugins
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.8.1
- OS Version:windows 7 Enterprise 64bits

Hello,

I have a big project with a lot of source code files and several languages used (c/c++, java, python).

I'm very interested in the autocomplete and code parsing features. I first tried to install the extension "C/C++" from Microsoft. It works great and the performances are good. You don't have to wait when ctrl clicking a symbol to go to the definition.

The problem comes when I try to install another language support. I've tried with "Language Support for Java(TM) by Red Hat". As soon as more than 1 extension is installed next to "c/c++", the performances become incredibly slow. 

From what I could see, the .db file created in the .vscode directoy grows more and more if you install more code parsing plugins. When I install only "C/c++", my DB file size is aroung 40MB. If I install Java support, it goes to 80MB and if I add the support for python it goes higher again. 

It looks that the slowdown is not related to the DB file size, but to the fact that more than 1 language support is enabled. 

Feel free to ask if you need more informations.

data.title: Editor: Add Git diff margin (Change Markers)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Win 10

There is a good plugin for Visual Studio which is called [GitDiffMargin](https://github.com/laurentkempe/GitDiffMargin). It shows diff by lines in the editor and you can revert particular changes.

### This is how it works in Visual Studio:
This is original code
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3620639/21383991/75832bee-c779-11e6-9cfc-97f1d3b84e04.png)

I deleted some code and the red arrow is appeared on the right side of line numbers
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3620639/21384030/a3233f6c-c779-11e6-9c6a-9c3490387a88.png)

I can click on the arrow and I will see the deleted code.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3620639/21384062/c89ff762-c779-11e6-809c-5334a28655d8.png)

If I click on `Rollback` button the deleted code will be restored
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3620639/21384144/37e6e842-c77a-11e6-9907-050925eb6fc8.png)

I think it is easier rather than copypaste lines in "Changes view"
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3620639/21384206/9f75755a-c77a-11e6-8c3e-cc505504ad0f.png)

data.title: Custom coloring for picked color theme
data.body: It would be great if there section in user settings appear where user can define custom coloring for picked color theme and those override or extend existing. Because now if I want to add just different color for function color i have to create new theme from scratch.

data.title: Streamline find & replace in selections
data.body:
Find and replace text in a selection is cumbersome. You have to
1) Mark the selection.
2) Hit CTRL+H to open the Find&Replace tool.
3) Remember to click "Find in selection". If you type into the "Find" field the selection is cleared and you have to start over again.
4) Click the "Find" field.
5) Erase previous text.
6) Enter text to find.
7) Hit tab to get to the "Replace" field.
8) Erase previous text.
9) Enter text to replace with.
10) Confirm by click or keyboard shortcut.

This could be streamlined a lot by getting rid of 3), 5) and 8):

- CTRL+H should auto-select "Find in selection" if there is a selection. This gets rid of 3).
- CTRL+H should always focus on the "Find" field (not "Replace") and select the text. I don't think anyone wants to enter the "Replace" text first and reuse the previous "Find" text or enter the "Find" text after the "Replace" text. This gets rid of 5).
- Finally, if you hit tab to jump from the "Find" field to the "Replace" field, the text should be selected, so that you can just start typing. This fixes 8).

OP: Ubuntu Linux 14.04.

data.title: toggleTerminal shortcut does not work on French keyboard layout
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:41:20.664Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-53-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|1.1.5|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.10|
|ActiveFileInStatusBar|RoscoP|1.0.2|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.4|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.7.1|
|relativepathrefactor|jakob101|0.8.0|
|docthis|joelday|0.3.5|
|Angular2|johnpapa|1.0.2|
|goto-last-edit-location|krizzdewizz|0.2.1|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.3|
|tsimporter|pmneo|1.2.13|
|gitblame|waderyan|1.3.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type CTRL+² to toggle the terminal as indicated in the shortcuts for a [French keyboard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AZERTY#/media/File:KB_France.svg) (notice the ² sign above the TAB key)
2. Nothing happens
3. Add
```
    { "key": "ctrl+'",                "command": "workbench.action.terminal.toggleTerminal" }
```
in the keybindings.json
4. The CTRL+² now works properly and toggles the terminal... 
5. But CTRL+' (below the 4 key) does not toggle the terminal as one would expect...

Notes:
1. looking at the binary form of keybindings.json, the single quote is indeed the expected 0x27
2. my ² key works properly otherwise... (I used it to type in this bug report).

data.title: Auto-indentation goes to wrong in arrow callbacks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider (04f541160e0d41be95df9a964b1b570aec549157)
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

![wrong-auto-indent](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1937871/21379909/e3887d04-c794-11e6-8e98-7d81aa168797.gif)

- In an arrow function as a callback.
- The start of the line is an opening parenthesis.
- I typed a `*` character.

I searched with `"auto indent js is:issue"` then I have not found the issue of this problem.
